abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Crisis
            Recovery Project for Yemen, Republic of were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: Yemens geographical conditions are
            treacherous and unique in the region. While the project
            benefitted from lessons of experience and ongoing ISP
            support, the operational trade-offs and administrative
            procedures should have been capable of responding to the
            local conditions. Inadequate attention was given to the
            delays in payments, lack of alternative payment distribution
            mechanisms in remote locations, and readiness of local
            organizations (or payment agents). The project suffered
            throughout, especially in the first 6 months, due to delayed
            funds transfer from Ministry of Finance, or MOF. The project
            team was highly concerned with regard to the lack of funds
            from MOF upfront before the project negotiation. The
            Government expressed concern of the fact that the cash
            benefits may not be utilized for the intended purposes and
            may not be making much development impact on the
            beneficiaries. The Bank team did not push hard for
            beneficiary assessment or designing the impact study, thus
            it is hard to reconcile beyond the objective of distributing
            cash. With another upcoming unconditional cash-transfer
            project, it is critical to consult with the Government and
            ensure that funds are allocated for an impact study and
            efforts are made early to prepare for it.
